questions.text: A 6-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of noisy breathing. Her parents state that her breathing has become progressively louder during this time. It is worse when she is lying on her back, feeding, and crying, and it improves when she is placed on her abdomen. Her mother also mentions that the girl has been regurgitating milk more than usual for the past few weeks. She was born at term and has been otherwise healthy. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her diet consists exclusively of formula milk. She is at the 65th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination discloses inspiratory stridor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus can cause inspiratory stridor and regurgitation of food, both of which are seen in this 6-month-old patient. However, these symptoms usually manifest within the first weeks of life, especially in cases of tracheal compression. In addition, vascular ring anomalies typically also result in dyspnea, dysphagia, and choking, none of which are seen here. Moreover, the stridor caused by a vascular ring classically improves with neck extension, not by lying in the prone position.

B) INCORRECT:

Cow's milk allergy in formula-fed infants can manifest with features of gastroesophageal reflux, including frequent regurgitation. However, food allergies are not associated with the progressive respiratory symptoms also seen in this infant, including noisy breathing while feeding and inspiratory stridor. In addition, this patient does not have other typical symptoms of food allergy, such as abdominal discomfort and diarrhea.

C) CORRECT:

Laryngomalacia is a congenital anomaly of laryngeal cartilage that causes the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration. Manifestations include inspiratory stridor that improves in the prone position and worsens in the supine position and during feeding and crying, as seen in this infant. In addition, 60–70% of children with laryngomalacia have symptoms of gastroesophageal and/or laryngopharyngeal reflux (e.g., frequent regurgitation) due to the higher intrathoracic pressures needed to overcome the inspiratory obstruction. Symptoms of laryngomalacia usually peak at 6–8 months of age, then resolve spontaneously by 2 years of age in ∼ 90% of cases as the cartilages strengthen. The diagnosis is confirmed with flexible laryngoscopy. Because laryngomalacia is a benign, self-limited condition, reassurance and close follow-up are generally sufficient.
Image Description:

Laryngoscopy

During inspiration, the lateral folds of the epiglottis curl inward, creating an omega shape. This finding may be a normal variation but is more frequently seen in laryngomalacia. Clinical correlation is required to establish a diagnosis of laryngomalacia.

D) INCORRECT:

Croup is most commonly seen in children between 6 months and 3 years of age and can manifest with inspiratory stridor. However, croup is typically more acute in onset than what is seen in this patient and is associated with other symptoms, including a prodrome (e.g., rhinitis, nasal discharge, congestion, low-grade fever), barking cough, and hoarseness, none of which are seen here. In addition, lying in the prone position typically exacerbates symptoms in patients with croup.

E) INCORRECT:

A foreign body aspiration (FBA) can manifest with inspiratory stridor. However, FBA is typically more acute in onset than what is seen in this patient and is associated with other symptoms, including choking, coughing, dyspnea, and hoarseness, none of which are seen here. Less commonly, patients can present weeks after an initial episode of FBA; however, typical symptoms in these cases are persistent or recurrent cough with fever.
questions.hint: In infants who are otherwise healthy, this condition is typically self-limited.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman is evaluated at her skilled nursing facility for an episode of increased wheezing. She has a history of chronic cough, wheezing, and dyspnea resulting in multiple hospitalizations for presumed asthma exacerbations in the past 3 years. She has previously been treated with inhaled bronchodilators and low-dose inhaled glucocorticoids, with minimal improvement.
She has never smoked and has no allergy symptoms or history of asthma. She did have an episode of severe pneumonia requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation approximately 5 years ago.
On examination, she is breathing comfortably with a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 95% while she is breathing ambient air. Her heart rate is 86 beats per minute, and she is afebrile. Auscultation reveals expiratory wheezing, most pronounced over her trachea. Ear, nose, and throat examination is normal.
A chest radiograph shows no opacities or other abnormalities.
Both standard and dynamic expiratory CT scans are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This case is most consistent with tracheomalacia. Tracheomalacia is a weakening of the walls of the trachea, leading to collapse of the airway during expiration (when the abnormality is intrathoracic). It often manifests with dyspnea, cough, and wheezing and is frequently misdiagnosed as asthma that is refractory to standard asthma management. Prolonged intubation is the most common cause of tracheomalacia in adults. CT imaging in affected patients may show findings indicative of dynamic tracheal collapse. Treatment often depends on how symptomatic the patient is. In patients who have significant symptoms or require repeated hospital admission, bronchoscopy with stent placement is considered first-line therapy. Surgical interventions may also be performed to prevent collapse of the trachea.

Key learning point: The most likely explanation for chronic dyspnea and wheeze that is not responsive to standard asthma management in a patient who has a history of extended intubation and a normal chest radiograph is tracheomalacia.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is characterized by wheezing, an abnormal chest radiograph, and elevated serum immunoglobulin E levels. Patients typically have central bronchiectasis and mucus plugging.

C) INCORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease (anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies) that manifests with acute kidney failure and hemoptysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly referred to as Churg-Strauss syndrome) is a small- to medium-vessel vasculitis that can manifest with sinusitis, wheezing, peripheral neuropathy, and eosinophilia. Patients with this condition have waxing and waning pulmonary opacities and multisystem symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis is associated with excessive mucus production and a chronic cough. Chest imaging would reveal dilated, irregular airways.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy has had a persistent barking cough for the past 5 months that is generally dry and nonproductive. His parents also report intermittent wheezing that is worse when he is supine or agitated; they deny snoring noises or stridor. A previous trial of albuterol led to a transient increase in the cough’s frequency and a worsening of the barking quality with no improvement in the wheeze.
The parents report that the patient does not gag with his bottle feeds and that feedings do not trigger or worsen the cough. He does not spit up or vomit on a regular basis. No other children reside in the home, and the parents have not witnessed any choking events.
The patient has had three to four prolonged episodes of cough requiring either supportive care or antibiotics but has never been diagnosed with pneumonia, sinusitis, or otitis media. He was born at 35 weeks’ gestation, was discharged after 7 days, and was never intubated. His vaccinations are up to date, and he is growing well along established weight and length trajectories. A recent chest radiograph was normal.
Physical examination today, including careful chest auscultation, is notable only for a subtle, intermittent monophonic wheeze in the midchest.
Which one of the following would confirm the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Response to an empiric trial of inhaled glucocorticoids

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has tracheomalacia, a disorder characterized by excessive collapsibility of the tracheal airway. Common signs and symptoms of this condition include a chronic barking cough and wheeze, which are exacerbated when the patient is supine and agitated; affected patients may also have airway-clearance difficulties, which can increase the risk for lower-airway infections.

Tracheomalacia often mimics asthma and croup, but one subtle differentiator is the nature of the wheeze: tracheomalacia is characterized by the presence of a homophonous or monophonic wheeze related to collapsibility of the large airways, whereas asthma manifests with a polyphonic wheeze related to the involvement of multiple small airways.

Another differentiator is the response to beta2-agonist medications like albuterol, which would typically improve asthma symptoms but can transiently worsen tracheomalacia (as they did in this patient). This worsening is likely related to the medication’s mechanism of action (airway smooth-muscle relaxation), which may reduce tracheal tone.

Tracheomalacia may be primary in etiology but may also occur secondary to congenital vascular anomalies (e.g., double aortic arch, pulmonary artery sling), genetic syndromes (e.g., trisomy 21, Pierre Robin sequence, DiGeorge syndrome), or injuries (e.g., foreign-body aspiration, tracheostomy, prolonged intubation, tetralogy of Fallot repair). It may also occur with bronchomalacia, as so-called tracheobronchomalacia.

Tracheomalacia is often diagnosed clinically, but further evaluation should be conducted to confirm the diagnosis when the child has difficulty feeding, is not gaining weight appropriately, or has repeated lower respiratory tract infections. Such evaluation is best accomplished with flexible bronchoscopy. Visualization of a tracheal lumen collapse >50% is consistent with clinically meaningful tracheomalacia.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic modality for a patient with suspected tracheomalacia or tracheobronchomalacia is flexible bronchoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Further chest imaging is likely to have a low diagnostic yield at this time, compared with bronchoscopy, and is not supported by expert consensus. Given that tracheomalacia is a dynamic problem of the airway, a single plain-film radiograph or CT scan is unlikely to provide helpful information. Fluoroscopy has poor sensitivity but high specificity for tracheomalacia. Dynamic MRI is an emerging modality in the diagnosis of dynamic airway issues, but it may be difficult to conduct in young children. CT angiography is a preferred imaging modality when vascular anomalies (e.g., pulmonary artery sling) are suspected.

C) INCORRECT:

Although chronic aspiration is a consideration in a young child with protracted cough, it is unlikely in this patient, who has no history of feeding difficulties or diagnosed pneumonias. A swallow study can therefore be deferred.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids are appropriate in the management of asthma but are not considered routine care in tracheomalacia or tracheobronchomalacia and are unlikely to result in a clinical response that could be considered diagnostic for either disorder.

E) INCORRECT:

Rigid bronchoscopy is not as sensitive as flexible bronchoscopy for evaluating the dynamics of the airway, because the positive pressure applied during the rigid procedure will stent the airway open. If tracheomalacia is suspected, a flexible bronchoscopy is required.

questions.text:
An 8-week-old infant is brought to the clinic by her mother due to noisy breathing present since birth. The mother notes that the sound intensifies when the infant is lying on her back and lessens when she is lying on her abdomen. The infant is otherwise tolerating feeds well and meeting developmental milestones. On examination, a high-pitched inspiratory noise is most prominent in the supine position, with no evident distress.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Subglottic stenosis involves fixed airway narrowing below the vocal cords, leading to persistent obstruction that does not change with position. It often presents with respiratory distress and may follow airway intervention or trauma, which are not evident here. The infant's symptoms vary with position, inconsistent with subglottic stenosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Tracheomalacia involves weakness of the tracheal cartilage, leading to airway collapse, particularly during expiration. It typically produces low-pitched, expiratory sounds or a seal-like cough, not the high-pitched inspiratory noise described. The noise in tracheomalacia does not usually lessen when the infant is prone.

C) CORRECT:

Laryngomalacia manifests with a high-pitched inspiratory stridor due to the collapse of supraglottic structures, such as the epiglottis and arytenoid cartilages, during inspiration. This condition results from the immaturity of laryngeal cartilages, leading to airway obstruction when negative intrathoracic pressure develops. The stridor intensifies in the supine position due to gravitational effects on the soft tissues, while prone positioning alleviates the noise. The benign course is evident as the infant feeds well and meets developmental milestones, aligning with the typical clinical profile of laryngomalacia.

Key learning point: Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in infants, characterized by inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position and improves in the prone position due to the collapse of supraglottic structures.

D) INCORRECT:

Vocal cord paralysis can cause stridor but usually presents with a weak or dysphonic cry and feeding difficulties. The stridor is generally static and not influenced by position changes. The infant's normal feeding and developmental milestones argue against vocal cord paralysis.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents because of noisy breathing and a harsh cough that has persisted for 4 months. His parents report that his breathing becomes louder and more labored when he is feeding, crying, or lying on his back, and seems to improve when he is calm or held upright. He was born at term. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He has had two episodes of upper respiratory infection, both of which were managed with supportive care. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He is meeting developmental milestones and is at the 25th percentile for weight and length. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 124/min, and respirations are 32/min. Physical examination shows mild intercostal retractions and a harsh, barking cough. There is prominent expiratory wheezing and a low-pitched, expiratory stridor that worsens with agitation. Pulse oximetry on room air is 98%. Chest radiograph shows no infiltrates or hyperinflation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic study?

choices.text: High-resolution computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest can evaluate airway anatomy and detect vascular rings or airway compression from mediastinal masses. However, this modality does not provide a dynamic, real-time assessment of tracheal collapse during respiration, which is necessary for diagnosing tracheomalacia. Additionally, HRCT exposes infants to ionizing radiation.

B) INCORRECT:

Esophageal barium swallow is used to evaluate tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) in infants. TEF typically manifests shortly after birth with coughing spells, rales, cyanotic episodes, and either aspiration pneumonia or gastric distention, depending on the fistula’s location. However, this child’s presentation (expiratory stridor, wheezing, symptom relief when upright) is more specific for a primary airway abnormality than for TEF.

C) INCORRECT:

Esophageal pH monitoring is indicated for suspected gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Although GERD may cause a chronic cough, it typically manifests with inspiratory rather than expiratory stridor. Furthermore, this child has persistent symptoms that worsen in the supine position, making GERD less likely. Finally, this patient does not have other typical features of GERD, such as feeding difficulties, failure to thrive, regurgitation, or persistent vomiting.

D) CORRECT:

Flexible bronchoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing suspected tracheomalacia. In pediatric patients, tracheomalacia usually manifests within the first 2–3 months of life with a barking cough and persistent, low-pitched, expiratory stridor and wheezing. Symptoms worsen with increased respiratory effort (e.g., crying, feeding) and when supine, and improve when the child is calm or upright. Flexible bronchoscopy allows direct visualization of the airway during respiration, and evidence of tracheal collapse with expiration confirms the diagnosis. This intervention also helps to exclude other structural lesions or foreign bodies. Tracheomalacia in children is often self-limiting and generally resolves by 2 years of age. Management of mild tracheomalacia consists of observation and reassurance, while severe cases may require surgical repair.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary function testing with spirometry is not feasible in infants and young children due to their inability to follow instructions for forced breathing maneuvers. Moreover, spirometry primarily assesses lower airway obstruction and cannot directly visualize dynamic upper airway collapse, making it less useful for diagnosing tracheomalacia.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of barking cough, noisy breathing while in a supine position, and expiratory wheezing and stridor since infancy, which suggests tracheomalacia.
